title: 115_s1153
content: The "Veterans Acquiring Community Care Expect Safe Services Act of 2017" or the "Veterans ACCESS Act" prevents certain health care providers from offering non-Department health care services to veterans. The "Veterans ACCESS Act" prohibits health care providers from offering non-Department health care services to veterans if they have violated certain policies or laws, had their credentials revoked, or had a term of imprisonment imposed. The "Veterans ACCESS Act" allows the Secretary to deny, revoke, or suspend a health care provider's eligibility to offer non-Department health care services if there are concerns about the provider's actions that may endanger veterans' health, safety, or welfare. This includes situations where the provider is under investigation by a state medical licensing board, has settled disciplinary charges related to their medical practice, or if the Secretary deems it necessary. The Secretary can suspend a health care provider's eligibility to offer non-Department health care services if they are suspended from serving as a Department health care provider. Within one year of the Act's enactment, the Secretary must review the employment status and history of each provider to determine their eligibility. The Comptroller General must submit a report on the Act's implementation within two years of its enactment. The Secretary can suspend health care providers from offering non-Department services if they are suspended from Department services. A report on the implementation of this section must be submitted to Congress, including the number of providers denied or suspended, impact on patient access to care, coordination with state medical boards, and recommendations from the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General can make recommendations on harmonizing eligibility criteria between Department and non-Department health care providers. Non-Department health care services include services provided at non-Department facilities, under the Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act, purchased through the Medical Community Care account, or with Veterans Choice funds. The Veterans Choice Fund under section 802 of the Department. The Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 was passed by the Senate on November 9, 2017, with Julie E. Adams as the Secretary.
